dt: {bc}the great arterial trunk that carries blood from the heart to be distributed by branch arteries through the body {dx}see {dxt|heart|heart|illustration}{/dx}

et: borrowed from Medieval Latin, borrowed from Greek {it}aortḗ{/it} "aorta, bronchial tubes (in plural {it}aortaí{/it}), knapsack," nominal derivative from the stem of {it}aeírein{/it} "to join, attach, harness," of uncertain origin

The word appears earlier as Middle English {it}aborchi, abhorti, adorte{/it} "aorta," comparable with Middle French {it}aborthi{/it} and Medieval Latin {it}adorti{/it}; these forms most likely reflect Latin translation of the Arabic versions of Greek medical texts. — The Greek medical term {it}aortḗ{/it} belongs to a small set of forms based on {it}aeírein{/it} that refer to both attachment and suspension, as {it}áōrto{/it} "was hung" ("[máchaira]… pàr xípheos méga kouleón aeìn áōrto" - "[the knife]… was always hung beside the great sheath of his sword"—{it}Iliad{/it} 3, 272), {it}aortḗr{/it} "belt or strap for hanging a sword or satchel," and {it}aórtēs{/it} "knapsack." Perhaps the aorta was pictured as an organ attached to and suspended from the heart in the way a scabbard is hung from a belt. Note that the verb {it}aeírein{/it} displays two sets of meanings, that of harnessing and attachment (outside of nominal derivation almost always with the prefix {it}syn-{/it} {et_link|syn-|syn-}) and of lifting or raising. Whether or not these should be regarded as two verbs of distinct origin or as semantic branches of the same verb is unclear. Though an Indo-European verb base {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}u̯er-{/it} can be reconstructed from the Greek evidence, there appear to be no definitely comparable forms outside Greek. See also {et_link|artery|artery}, {et_link|meteor|meteor}.
shortdef: the great arterial trunk that carries blood from the heart to be distributed by branch arteries through the body

dt: {bc}the curved part of the {d_link|aorta|aorta} that connects the ascending aorta with the descending aorta and from which the {d_link|brachiocephalic artery|brachiocephalic artery}, left {d_link|carotid artery|carotid artery}, and left {d_link|subclavian artery|subclavian artery} arise

shortdef: the curved part of the aorta that connects the ascending aorta with the descending aorta and from which the brachiocephalic artery, left carotid artery, and left subclavian artery arise —called also aortic arch
